text: The bells of a Gothic church are ringing down upon a come square near downtown Hartford. The crisp fall day is aliv with color, as cornflower skies burst through the autumn and golds, setting off the clean brick buildings and fres painted homes that so proudly distinguish this New Englan township. Music over OPENING CREDITS. We see a powder blue, ‘56 Chevrolet turn onto the main ro its way into town.

The Chevrolet stops in front of a small dance school just State St. and an attractive, red-haired woman in her mid- thirties emerges from the car, wearing sunglasses and a scarf. She says hello to a mother and daughter exiting th school on her way inside, returning a moment later with a strawberry-haired girl in ballet clothes. CATHY WHITAKER, having collected her 8-year-old daughter JANICE from ball class is finally returning home from another busy day.
Cathy's car is turning onto a well-tended, residential street, full of traditional black-shuttered, white wood homes, each set back on spacious lawns against, the blaze autumn color

She turns into the driveway of a large, fastidiously landscaped 2-story home, with a slate roof and flagstone walkway. DAVID WHITAKER, a typical 11-year-old boy, with- hair like his dad’s, is circling around the front of the house on his bright red Schwinn:
Mother! Mother! Can I sleep over at Hutch's tonight? Mrs. Hutchinson gave permission.
(from the car) Not tonight, David. (MORE)
CATHY(cont 'd) Your father, and I are going out and I need you to, look after your sister.
Aww, shucks.
Now move your school bag, David, so mother can park. The Whitaker's maid SYBIL, a handsome black woman in her early 30's, is just coming down the front steps to the ca
(hopping out) Sherry Seeger says they only' cost something like five or six dollars Please mother, please can I?
(opening her door) Oh Sybil, thank heavens!
Well I knew you were going to the grocery -
David, please help Sybil unload the car.
How come Janice doesn’t gotta?
Doesn't have to. Because Janice is carrying in all her, belongings an marching straight upstairs into the bath. She steps out of the car loaded down with laundered cloth and packages.
Your father and I have an engagement so I want you both to have a nice early dinner. And help Sybil.
(not exactly in sync) Yes, ma’am.
Sybil, did Mr. Whitaker call while I was out?
No, Mrs. Whitaker. Not since you've been gone.
How do you like that guy. Big time executive and he still can't remember a single social obligation!
So mother can I? Please can I get them?
Janice I said we'll discuss it with your father. Now hurry on inside. David, put your bike away and help Sybil with the groceries! Where's your jacket?
Inside. Cathy turns to see her best friend ELEANOR FINE, a lean blond woman in her early 40's, just turning up her drive shiny green Imperial.
Well hello, stranger! Aren't I seeing you in about three hours time? Eleanor is stepping out of her car.
You are. But I just left the caterers this instant and I had to dash over.
You have the samples?
You bet.
Ooh. Come inside.  They start into the house.
I can only stay a second.
You just caught me, actually - David! what did I tell you?
I'm getting the last bag!
Inside, Janice is practicing some ballet steps by a large stone fireplace. Eleanor is in the midst of showing Cathy color samples for the big company party it is their annua venture to host.
And imagine with the table setting I showed you. The aqua trim? Is that smart?
Oh yes.
You like?
Mmm-hmm.
(starting to put things away ) Alright. So I'll call the caterers in the morning and you confirm with Dorothy on the deposit - and honey, we're in business.
Magnavox ‘57, here we come.
You betcha.
Mother, look!
Janice I thought I told you to go start your bath! You know your father and I -
Just this one part, pleeease.
Alright, bunt lickety-split. Janice performs a few steps for her mother and Eleanor as David pours over the TV guide on the couch.
Oh, will you look at that?
That's lovely darling.
She's getting so grown up.
Mother, can I stay up and watch The Californians - Please!
Janice, honey, watch the lamp!
Ta-da! Eleanor and Cathy applaud Janice who beams in delight.
Ohh!
That was lovely, dear. Now hurry on up and get out of those clothes or mother's going to be late. Janice turns, still beaming, and dashes up the stairs.
I better run. I still have loads to do.
Well I can imagine, with Mona Lauder and that little white glove of hers...

Aren't social mores the most dreadful bore? Mona's invited us at least three times last year so of course there wasn't a thing I could do. And Stan sees Fred at the club... Cathy opens the door for her.
Eleanor starts down the front steps of the house toward h car.
Thanks for stopping by.
I'll see you at eight!
You know Frank. On the dot! Cathy waves goodbye and closes the door.

Janice is curled into an armchair in the soft glow of Cat vanity, watching her mother do her make-up in the mirror. Cathy is dressed for the evening in sleeveless emerald gr setting off the tangerine of her hair.
Mother?
(doing her lipstick) Uh-huh?
When you were a little girl you looked like me, right?
Uh-huh.
So when I grow up does that mean I'll look like you?
Is that what you want darling, to look like me?
Yes. I hope I look exactly as pretty as you.
What a lovely compliment coming from my perfectly lovely daughter. She picks up her wristwatch and glances at the time.
Seven-fifteen!, Where on earth is your father? She gets up and walks over to a dresser.
Mother?
(searching for something) What is it, dear?
Can I try putting lipstick on me?
(starting out the door) Not tonight, Janice. Mother’s going to be late. Sybil!
Cathy is starting down the stairs.
(off) Yes, Mrs. Whitaker?
Did I leave my gloves on the hall table?
(off) Yes, ma’am. I see them.
You know it's nearly twenty after and Mr. Whitaker still hasn't phoned! Sybil meets Cathy at the foot of the stairs with the glov
Thank you, Sybil... - I'm at my wits end. I even tried calling his office, though I knew there wouldn't be anyone - The phone RINGS. Sybil goes to the hall table to answer i
Well I certainly hope that's him now. Because if it isn't -
Whitaker residence. (brief silence, then stiffly) Yes sir. One moment, please.
Who is it?
(Lowered voice) Police department. Cathy frowns, taking the phone.
Hello?
(through receiver) Yes. Am I speaking with a Mrs. Frank Whitaker?
Yes.
Of 1616 Sycamore Drive?
Yes.
One moment please. The OFFICER hands the phone over to FRANK WHITAKER, a dar haired, big-boned man in his early forties, who has just finished wiping his ink-stained fingers with a rag.
Cathy?
Frank! Frank, what happened? Are you alright?
I'm fine. Everything's fine. It was a big - mix-up, the whole thing. But you gotta come get me. They won't - let me leave on my own.
Oh, Frank. Don't worry, darling. I'll be there as quickly as I can. (she hangs up the phone)
Is there anything I can do, Mrs. Whitaker?
No. Thank you Sybil. Just keep an eye on the children. I'm sure I won't be long. Cathy grabs her purse and coat and rushes for the door.
Cathy's car pulls up in front of the lamp-lit police stat She hurries out of the car, still in her evening clothes, up the stone steps of the precinct  10.
Cathy walks over to the OFFICER at the desk
Can I help you ma’am?
Yes, I'm here to meet my husband. The name's Whitaker, Frank Whitaker.
Here we go. Room 103. If you'll follow me, ma'am.
Cathy signs the report and hands it to the BAIL CLERK.
This is your copy, ma'am, and your receipt.
Thank you. Then the door opens and Frank walks through it.
Oh, Frank! Cathy rushes to him and they embrace. As they leave, two of the officers are still watching.
Cathy drives while Frank broods in the passenger seat. RE PROJECTED streetlights send charcoal shadows across their faces.
I'll tell you one thing. If it hadn't been for that sniveling junior cop they'd have never gone through the whole charade in the first place!... / (MORE)
FRANK(cont 'd) Stead of trying to save face. I saw the guy they were after - the ‘loiterer’. They wouldn't even listen to me! I tell you, I have half a mind to sue the pants off the whole precinct.
Or... you could simply forget the whole thing ever happened.
(takes a breath) I suppose you're right. Brief silence.
(a bit cautiously) So were there - drinks after work?
What do you mean?
I thought they said something... Intoxication level, something-or- other - ?
Christ! I had a lousy cocktail with Bill after work, going over the portfolio! Should I be arrested for that too?
Of course not, darling.
The whole thing’s just put me ina fowl state.
I know, dear. You just try to rest. We’1l be home in no time.
Cathy stands in semi-darkness, on the phone with Eleanor. finds the police report in her purse.  12.

He’s fine... The car’s fine. Frank says it was the bumper that got hit, but you know me. I can’t tell the difference... I’m just sorry we had to miss it... I know... She drops the papers into the waste-basket.
Frank sits in bed with an open book on his lap, staring i space. The door squeaks open and he looks over.
She was fine. Said it was a dreadful bore, what with Mona Lauder and her gossip.
(depleted) Cathy, I’m sorry.

(embracing him) Darling, you’ve nothing to be sorry for. It was all just a silly wretched mistake! They kiss deeply and he takes her in his arms. Cathy clos her eyes and begins caressing his shoulders and neck. But Frank stops and pulls away. She looks at him.
Feel so tired. He turns and lays down into bed and she caresses the side his head with her hand.
Course you do. You sleep now. She switches off the light, pulls up his blanket and slow walks to the bathroom.
The Whitaker clan are all seated around the breakfast roo table finishing a breakfast of bacon and eggs.  13.
Pop, Hutch says if the Russian's drop a bomb on us we couldn't drop one back on them. Is that true?
Well, son, I'm afraid Hutch has a point there.
Why, pop? Why couldn't we?
Drink your orange juice David.
I already drank mine. Look father!
Attagirl!
Pop, why?

(glancing at the clock) Would you look at the time? It's already a quarter after! You kids are going to miss your bus! Sybil can you help me get their coats? Sybil helps Cathy distribute coats and lunch-boxes, and h them out of the kitchen.
Alright, now. Say goodbye to your father.
Bye, father. (she kisses him)
Goodbye, kitten.
Bye, pop!
Have a good day at school, son. David is first out the door.  14.
Janice, have you got your notebook?
Yes, Mother. David swings open the front door of the house. We can hea the bus approaching.
(off) The bus is here!
David - your lunch! Cathy takes it from Sybil and rushes after him.
David! He swoops back in, grabs it, and is off again, followed b Janice.
Bye, mother!
Have a nice day at school, dear Cathy pecks her on the cheek and she runs out the door.
The bus pulls up in front of the house as David and Janic running and Cathy waves.
Bye! The big yellow door closes behind them and the bus pulls down the street. A small truck is just pulling up to the house which reads DEAGAN GARDEN SUPPLY.
Cathy is walking back' into the house as Frank emerges fr the kitchen, gathering his things for work.  15.
I thought you were going to have another piece of toast?
It's late. I should get over there.
Well can I at least fix you lunch?
No, thank you, dear. I've got lunch meetings all week long. It's portfolio season! The doorbell rings.
(calling) Sybil, if that's the milkman, his check is in the kitchen drawer!
(off) Yes, ma’am! Cathy helps Frank on with his overcoat
Well I'm just glad you're feeling better, dear.

Thank you, darling. Frank embraces Cathy and kisses her warmly just as - BOOM a camera flash ignites them, and they turn. Standing beside Sybil in the entryway is MRS. LEACOCK , a grey-faced woman in her 60's, and a young PHOTOGRAPHER wi camera.
Pardon me, ma'am, sir.
Excuse me, Mrs. Whitaker. This is - Mrs. Leacock? She says she had an appointment with you this morning?  16.
Oh Jimminy - I completely forgot the time! Yes, of course, Mrs. Leacock, please come in.
I do apologize, Mrs. Whitaker, but candid views are always the best.
Darling, this is Mrs. Leacock, the lady I told you about, from the Weekly Gazette.
Ah, yes. The fine lady who wants to air all our dirty secrets. (shaking her hand) How do you do, Mrs. Leacock?
Fear not, Mr. Whitaker. We at the Gazette ascribe to only the highest of professional standards.
Well I'm glad to hear it. Now if you'll all please excuse me, I have some professional standards of my own to keep up. (kissing Cathy) Goodbye, darling.
Goodbye, dear.
(nodding goodbye) Mrs. Leacock...
Pleasure, Mr. Whitaker. Franks gives a final wave to the room and is gone.
Your husband's a very charming man Mrs. Whitaker.

Thank you. We're rather fond of him ourselves. Please, won't you come in and make yourselves at home.  17. Cathy escorts them into the living room and over to the c while untying her kitchen apron. Cathy dress.
AS you can see, I'm just running a bit behind schedule today.
That's quite alright, dear. sits down opposite her, casually smoothing her hair and
I suppose I still can't imagine why in the world you’d want an interview with me in the first place. It couldn't possibly be very interesting for your readers.

The readers of the Weekly Gazette, Mrs. Whitaker, are women just like yourself, with families and homes to keep up. A good society paper need not be a gossip rag. You are the proud wife of a successful sales executive, planning the parties and posing at her husband's side on the advertisements. She refers to a framed magazine advertisement on the wall showing Cathy and Frank posed in front of their TV with t heading: MR. & MRS. MAGNAVOX CHOOSE NOTHING BUT THE BEST
Suddenly,
To everyone here in Connecticut you are Mr. and Mrs. Magnavox.

I suppose I should be flattered. I just don't feel I'm so very different from anyone else, really. I like to shop and wear a pretty dress every now and then. But really my life is just like any other wife or mother's - I don't suppose I've ever really wanted anything - through the window, Cathy glimpses someone moving through her backyard. She stands.  18.
What is it, dear?
I think I just saw someone walking through our yard. Cathy walks to the french doors leading to the backyard. There she sees A tall black man standing outside, hunching over somethin
What on earth...?
(standing, seeing) Oh my. Cathy opens the door.
Mrs. Whitaker - Perhaps you should call the police -

The Whitaker backyard is an ample, two-tiered expanse, wi flagstone walkways and fastidiously landscaped hedges, tr and flower-beds bordering the swimming-pool and lawn. Cathy takes a few cautious steps in the direction of the stranger.

Excuse me. Can I help you? The man looks up from a shrub of evergreens, squinting. T is RAYMOND DEAGAN, 40 years old, good-looking. He steps toward her, looking slightly irritated himself. Cathy takes an involuntary step back
Who are you?
Ma'am, I'm sorry. My name's Raymond Deagan. I'm Otis Deagan's son. I've just been - taking over some of his jobs since he -  19.
You're Otis's son?
Yes.
Well I'm - terribly sorry for speaking to you in that manner. I didn't know who was in my yard.
No need.
How is your father? I knew he was in the hospital.
Yes, I - My father passed away, I'm afraid.
No! I had no idea! I'm so very sorry. (putting her hand on his arm) Please accept our deepest condolences. Your father was a wonderful, dedicated man.
Thank you. The phone rings from inside the house.
We hear Sybil answering it as Mrs. Leacock watches Cathy through the window - just removing her hand from Raymond' arm.
Sybil steps out to the porch from the kitchen door
Mrs. Whitaker? I have Greenhill Caterers,on the line!  20.
Thank you, Sybil! (to Raymond) I'm sorry. Would you excuse me a moment?
Of course. Cathy hurries back inside.
Mrs. Leacock, I'm terribly sorry! I'll just be a minute more!

Frank is walking briskly down the wide passageway of his floor at Magnavox, passing secretarial pools and other employees with a smile. Triangles of morning sun bleach t wood-paneled walls of the floor's lean, modern decor He passes a sprite little secretary named Kitty.
Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.
Morning Kitty. Lovely dress you're wearing.

Thank you, sir. Frank continues on towards the outer office of the execut suite where his secretary, MARLENE, is stationed beneath large abstract wall-hanging. Standing opposite, pooling over a file is STAN FINE, Eleanor's husband, a tall, slightly greying man with a be who works right below Frank in the Hartford division.
Morning, Marlene, Stan!
Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.  21.
So how's the second best golfer in Hartford this morning?
Someone break the books already? Don't tell me our wives' party budgets have finally come in.
Almost as fatal. Millstein called. Looks like New York just shaved a week off portfolio deadline.
You gotta be kidding me.
I wish I were.
What're they trying to do, strangle us to death?! Does Dennis know?
Called him first thing.
Alright. Get Dennis and the others and call a portfolio meeting for lunch today. Marlene, see if you can move production review to dinner.
Yes, sir.
And would you get my wife on the phone? (to Stan) Thanks, Stan. Frank pats Stan on the shoulder and marches through the l wood-paneled door of his office.

Frank drops his briefcase and sits down heavily at the la handsomely ornamented desk.  22. He takes a breath before turning and quietly opening a lo drawer, pulling out a quart of Jack Daniels and pouring a swig into his coffee. As he stashes it away we hear
(on intercom) Sir? I have Mrs. Whitaker on line 1.
Thank you, Marlene. Frank takes a slurp, swallows and pushes line 1 on his ph
Cathy, is that you, dear?
Cathy speaks to Frank from the phone in the hall.

Did you forget something?... Oh, Frank... I’m sorry, dear... No, I understand... I just wish you wouldn’t overwork yourself, Frank. Especially after... I know - I know, dear... I will... See you then... Goodbye, dear. Cathy hangs up the phone and starts back into the living room.
I’m terribly sorry for the interruptions. Where was it you wanted me?
Just one more at the fireplace. Cathy walks over to the fireplace where she puts one hand the mantle and turns toward the photographer.
Right there. Now smile. Cathy smiles.
Isn't that darling.  23.
Hold it... FLASH.
We descend from a moonlit night past the Hartford skyline the awning of Sammy's Steakhouse, where Frank and four ST MEMBERS are just emerging.
(slightly slurred) Well I guess that about wraps it up (shaking hands) ) Bob, Rick. Gentlemen.
You're sure you're alright getting home, sir?
Thank you, Davis. But as 2nd in command of the US McMillan I do feel equipped to locate my car without cover.
Very good, sir.

Bright and early gentlemen! They say goodnight and we follow Frank as he proceeds dow the pink, lamplit blocks of downtown Hartford. He passes teenagers clumped in cars, making out. He passes a HOOKER.
Where ya headed, tiger? Frank looks away as he passes. When he looks up again he The marquee of a movie theater glowing up ahead.  24.
Frank approaches the tungsten awning of the old, 20's-sty cinema, currently featuring half-price double-bills. He stops. The marquee reads: THREE FACES OF EVE and MIRACLE IN THE RAIN.

ONSCREEN: We are in the middle of THREE FACES OF EVE. Ray Burr is questioning one of Joanne Woodward's more timid personalities. Frank is walking in from the rear of the theater. He stop along the back wall and stands watching, muted in shadow Edward Hopper's usherette. ONSCREEN: Joanne Woodward is becoming agitated. She start switching into another personality. A dark-haired man is getting up from his seat and walking the direction of the Gentleman's Lounge. Frank notices hi pausing a moment at the foot of the small, carpeted stair just as a second man approaches. The dark-haired man spot the second one and proceeds briskly down the stairs. The second man follows, looking around nervously as he goes. Frank stares darkly down the empty corridor.
Cathy sits in the lilac glow of her lamp-lit writing tabl addresses party gunshots can be heard from downstairs. Cathy turns the face of her desk-clock to see the time. I reads 10:36.
(getting up) Oh, for heavens sake... DAVID!

Music escorts us from the dark of the living room to the chestnut glow of the den where David sits watching television.  25. Sybil inventories serving ware in the dining room, as Cat makes her way downstairs with writing tablet and pen.
David, this is the third time I've told you to turn that infernal racket off and get into bed! Do you know what time it is?
Mother please can I just this once stay up and watch the -
No, David, you most certainly may not and that is final.
(reluctantly turning it off) Ah, jeez...
That's not the sort of language we use in this house! Now march! And don't forget to wash your teeth! As David swaggers off Cathy straightens up the couch.
Oh, Sybil, be sure and check dinner forks as well. I seem to recall being short last year.
I thought it was salad forks we were short on. Cathy begins closing drapes in the living room windows.
Perhaps you're right. Whatever it was, I'd like to try and order a set before the party.
That shouldn't be a problem.
You know, Sybil, I think this may just turn out to be our best one yet.  26.
Well I'm sure Mr. Whitaker will be extremely proud. Cathy turns off a lamp by the window and parts the drapes moment. She glances out into the silent, blue-edged night.

A man on a ladder is replacing the letters on the theater marquee as Frank files out of the theater amid the strang week-night crowd. He stops a moment beneath the canopy of bulbs. There's a trill of laughter from down the street and Fran turns. The two men from the movie theater are walking off, one o them laughing. They turn the corner. Frank squints, looking after. And with a frown of curiosi and some unsteadiness, he begins to follow.

The two men are crossing the shadowy side-street. One of can still be heard as they approach a dark, inconspicuous door, a few steps down from street-level. They open it, sending a sudden flood of green into the darkness, then quickly vanish inside. Frank stares after, stuck between intrigue and fear. He follows.

Fran's is a small, burgundy-walled “gentlemen's bar', wit black upholstery and a mint-green light embalming its wel groomed clientele - most of whom take subtle notice of Fr as he enters the room. Out of nowhere a voice is heard -
Identification please.
(turning, startled) What?  27. A thin man in his 50's with a pencil-thin mustache stands beside the door.
Identification, drivers license.
Oh. Sure. Frank shows him his wallet
Thank you, sir. Have a pleasant evening.
Thank you. Frank proceeds cautiously into the room, heading to the b A SPANISH BARTENDER accent nods slowly as he approaches.
Yes, sir? What can I get you this evening?
Just a Johnny Walker, please. Neat.

Yes, sir. Frank takes out a cigarette and lights it. He glances sti across the room. The plucked and coiffed patrons, seated mostly alone, gla back with the same stiff, self-consciousness. The men fro the theater sit in some corner rapt in conversation. Frank's drink is set on the bar and he takes a fast, deep sip, shiny with perspiration. Frank puts down a bill and takes a long, relaxing drag of his cigarette.
One more of the same. Frank looks over and sees a clean-cut BLOND MAN (early 30 at the bar. He exhales. The blond man glances over and smiles cautiously. Frank smiles cautiously back  28.
There you are, sir. The blond man remains looking at Frank a moment before picking up his drink and starting back to his table. Frank watches him go.
Frank closes the front door behind him and starts slowly the stairs of the house, black on shadowy blue, as a slow burden of music rises. He stops at the foot of his bedroom door and stares at
Cathy, copper and blue, asleep in bed. Music lightens as we

We float out from a newspaper photograph of Frank and Cat kissing in the latest Hartford Weekly Gazette to reveal Eleanor, reading aloud from the paper. The door to the ho is open as Cathy and her arriving guests, DOREEN and NANC stand around listening, having obviously been stopped in their tracks to do so. Cathy holds a lilac scarf under he chin as a feisty wind whips through the trees and sends a circus of leaves through the sky.

‘So does the fabled maxim hold that behind every great man there resides a great lady? In this case - wife, mother and Mrs. Magnovox herself - Cathleen Whitaker proves that it does, a woman as devoted to her family as she is kind to Negroes’!! They burst into laughter.  29.
To Negroes?!
(grabbing the paper) Let me see that! Oh my heavens. What on earth was that woman thinking?
How did that come up?
Cathy? Oh she's been liberal ever since she played summer stock at college with all those steamy Jewish boys! Why do you think they used to call her red!
Oh for heaven sakes, come inside. Before Joe McCarthy comes driving by! Eleanor laughs and Cathy hands her back the paper.
Here. Suddenly a strong gust of wind sweeps Cathy's scarf right her head and up over the side of the house.
Uh-oh!
Oh, no! I love that scarf!
Oh, I'm sure it just blew behind the house somewhere.
Oh, for heaven's sake. They continue back inside the house.
This really isn't your day, is it?
So did they really call you ‘red’?  30. Eleanor laughs some more.
Oh Nancy, honestly!
The ladies are just finishing lunch, a bit tipsy from the daiquiris.
Can I get anyone another daiquiri?
Oh no. One's my limit.
Better not.
El? Eleanor holds out her glass. Cathy smiles, refilling it.
Thanks doll. (takes a sip) Alright now girls, no more beating around the bush. Nancy?
I can't.
Come on now. Can't be that bad.
Alright. (she smiles bashfully) Well... Mike insists on once a week. The laddies giggle, except for Cathy, who stands holding pitcher of daiquiris.
Ah, you got off easy!
Once a week?  31.
Yea, you’re lucky. Ron’s more like two or three.
Really? Three?
And how.

That’s nothing. Girlfriend of mine? (to Cathy) Shirley Dawson - (back to everyone) Her husband? Every night-o-the- week... plus three times more on the weekend! Can you imagine? Cathy returns the pitcher to the bar.
Oh, my.
How long have they been married?
Well, long enough! Seven years? Eight? Doreen and Nancy break into more giggles as Cathy stands moment, reflected in thought in the marbled mirror, a not music accompanying.
Cathy stands in front of her house waiving goodbye to Eleanor, Doreen and Nancy, who make their way to their ca
It was lovely, Cathleen!
Thanks, girls.
Bye, now.  32.
Chicken was divine.
Thanks, El.
I’1l1 call you tomorrow!
Bye.
Thanks again, hon! It was all too divine!
Thanks, El. I'll call you tomorrow.

Bye! Cathy is about to turn back into the house when she puts hand to her head, remembering her scarf. She glances over toward the side of the house and starts slowly down the f steps, glancing around the yard as she goes. By now the wind has died down and a pale opal light has t the edge off the sun. A soft spell of music begins. She doesn't see it along the front hedges and continues o the side of the house. She turns the corner, glancing up the roof. Suddenly
Could this possibly - Cathy turns with a start. Raymond is standing along the side of the house holding h lilac scarf.
I'm sorry.
No - You found it!  33.
Yes - It was... (starts walking toward her) hanging off one of the birch's down front.
It's just been so windy. I was just going back in the house when it just - Raymond hands Cathy the scarf.
. sailed off my head - Thank you.
I had a feeling it might have been yours.
Who else could have been so absentminded?
No. The color. Just seemed right.
Well thank you, Mr. Deagan. For finding it.
Please. Call me Raymond.
Thank you. Raymond. She smiles and they begin walking back to the front yard.
Everything looks wonderful by the way.
Well good. Pop’s a tough act to follow when it comes to his work. But I think we got everything pretty under control. Cathy looks at him a moment.  34.
I’m sure it hasn’t been easy. Taking over for your father so quickly.
Well I guess between pa’s business my shop, and looking after my little girl, there’s not much time left for reflecting.
I didn't know you had children.
Just the one. Sarah's her name.
And how old is Sarah?
Eleven years old, yea. And the sun and the moon to me.
Well I'm sure she's a lovely child. You and your wife must be very proud.
Well, Mrs. Deagan - my wife - she passed away when Sarah was about five.
Oh Raymond. I'm so sorry.
Well. Thank you. We do - we do just fine, Sarah and I. (reaching for his wallet) I have a - picture somewhere... (opening it for Cathy) There. That's Sarah.
Oh, she's darling. Look at those eyes... And what's this I hear about a shop?
The plant shop? Yea. It's just a little place, down on Hawthorn. (MORE)
RAYMOND( cont'd) Started out as a service for gardeners, ordering plants and fertilizer. ‘Til I opened the store. ‘Bout six years ago. The only thing that business degree's been good for yet.
Well that's marvelous, Raymond. You should be very proud.
Well. If you’re ever in the neighborhood you be sure and stop by. We have some lovely houseplants.
Well I certainly will.
Alright then. She smiles goodbye and walks back into the house.
Cathy closes the door behind her. Right away we hear Sybi from the kitchen door.
(off) Mrs. Whitaker? I have that list whenever you’re ready!
Thanks, Sybil. I’1l come get it now. Where has this day gone to?
From just outside the blaze of the kitchen we find Cathy Sybil busily serving dinner to the children.
Elbows off the table, David!
Eeuu - I hate those!  36.
I’m sorry, Janice. But for a growing girl, who needs her vitamins and is studying ballet -
Oh mother! You said... You said -
I said we would discuss it and we discussed it. Now I don’t want to hear another word about it. I certainly don't like thinking I've raised such spoiled children.
What do you mean children? I'm not the one who wants some dopey ballet shoes!
Slippers! The telephone rings. Sybil is carrying a tray of food.

If that's your father... Don't worry, Sybil, I'll get it. (she picks up the phone) Hello? Frank? You haven't left?... Oh no, not again... I know Frank but every week... I know, I know darling... I won't... Alright... Goodnight, dear. (she hangs up the phone)
What! He's not coming home again?
Father never wants to come home!
Oh Janice, he most certainly does. It's just a terribly busy time for your father right now, and he's under a great deal of strain.
(to Janice) Yea!  37.
Shut up.
You know what, Sybil? Wrap up a plate for Mr. Whitaker. I'm just gonna go and take it over there myself.
All the way downtown?

It's really not so far. Anyway, the children are nearly through, and knowing Mr. Whitaker, I'll at least be sparing him another night of pretzels and coffee. Cathy picks up her coat from a corner chair and starts ou the door as we

Cathy, emerging through the shimmer of a revolving door, quiet dissonance emerges, building slowly throughout the scene. She walks across the large marble-floored lobby, Tupperware in hand, to the night-watch's table.
I'm just dropping something off to my husband on the twelfth floor Mr. Whitaker. The NIGHT-WATCH motions her in and Cathy continues briskl the elevators.

The elevator doors open. Cathy steps out onto the darkene floor and starts down the central corridor toward the executive suite. As she approaches the outer office she realizes there is one else in sight, no lights, no sign of work.
(to herself, perplexed) Frank?  38. She glances around as she continues, doubtfully, in the direction of his office. Then she notices A soft strip of light coming from beneath his office door
(shaking her head) Oh, Frank... In a rush of wifely sympathy she walks up to the door and politely opens it.
Frank - ?

Instantly she sees it: a shirtless blond man with loosene pants locked in a writhing kiss with another man in shirtsleeves, who appears to be fondling him. Immediately they turn and jolt apart. It takes her a moment to regist that the man in shirtsleeves is Frank. All at once Cathy gasps, pulling back and turning, droppi her Tupperware. She shuts her eyes and struggles for brea Inside we can hear the men scrambling to dress, knocking something over in the process. Suddenly Cathy turns facing the door, reeling, horrified. Music burns with the weight of realization as she starts stepping slowly, staring out in confusion and disbelief. She glimpses something through the crack of the door and stops. Frank catches sight of her from inside. Cathy stares. He looks down. Suddenly the blond man slips out past him, darting briskly down the hall. He disappears down the stairwell where we can hear his echoey steps slowly fadin away . All at once Cathy turns and runs, music returning with thunder and storm.
Cathy!  39. She runs down the hall to the elevator, bangs on the butt until it opens and throws herself inside.
Cathy gasps for air inside the dim, mirror-lined elevator trying to pull her hair over her eyes and shut out the wo forever.
Music bathes the shadowy quiet of the Whitaker exterior, darkness brushed blue with moonlight, as we glide in slow toward the living room window.

Music continues as we creep in slowly on Cathy silhouette against the glass, frozen in thought. Suddenly there’s th sound of keys at the door and we stop, silent. Cathy does move. Frank quietly shuts the door behind him and turns around. Dead, eerie silence. He removes his coat, hangs it on the rack, and takes a qu out of the closet. He turns and stops, sensing something. Then he sees her. Cathy just stares. But there’s a new kind of death in her face. Frank drops his head. He remains still for several second Finally
(from a strange distance) Mr. Maynard... left an estimate... for the roof. I put it in the kitchen. (silence) Twelve hundred something. I assume you’11 want - (silence) a second opinion...
Cathy -
I can’t - Silence.
I know. Silence. He drops his head.
I don’t - (doesn’t finish)
What?
I don't even... Frank looks up. He sighs with resignation.
See... Once. Long time ago. Long long time ago. I had... problems. I just figured... that was - that was it. (shaking his head) I never... imagined...
You had... problems?
Yes.
You never... spoke to anyone? A doctor?
No.
No one? Frank shakes his head.
I don't... I don't understand. 40.  41.
I don't either.
What if... I mean there must be people who - who...
I don't know.
There must be. Frank suddenly seems a hundred miles away.
Frank? Frank can barely look at her let alone respond.
Because... (suddenly shaky) Otherwise, I just - I don't know what - Oh Frank! Soft music begins. Frank closes his eyes and quietly nods Cathy exhales a tiny breath of relief.
(softly) Thank you. He slowly-turns and Cathy watches as he starts up the sta music expanding.
The last Autumn leaves are falling on this bright, bluste afternoon in the Hartford business district. Cathy's car be seen turning onto the main road and continuing into to

The large, modern medical complex stretches out against c blue skies and white clouds. Down below we see Cathy pull into the Municipal lot. The white-capped attendant hands a ticket, raises the gate and smiles as she proceeds in.  42. Cathy walks up to the front of one of the buildings, chec her watch and glances around for Frank. In a small park opposite, a young couple can be seen lean against a tree, kissing. The girl pulls away but the boy pursues eagerly, stroking the girl's hair and whispering her ear. Cathy watches, closer (with a rear-projected background). The boy tries kissing her again, but the girl turns away, glancing toward Cathy self-consciously. Cathy looks down. She checks her watch again and glances around one more time for Frank. We see him now, just crossing the street Cathy waves, starting over in his direction. They meet an begin walking up the slope of stairs.
The RECEPTIONIST is swinging open the door of the waiting room.
Mr. and Mrs. Whitaker .?
Yes. Cathy and Frank get up from their chairs. DR. Bowman, an imposing man in his fifties with a distinc streak of white in his hair, is just stepping through the door as music fades.
This is Dr. Bowman.
(shaking Frank's hand firmly) Mr. Whitaker? How do you. (politely taking Cathy's) Mrs. Whitaker? How lovely.
Thank you.  43.

Mr. Whitaker, Mrs. Whitaker. As someone who's been around numerous couples like yourselves, I realize how difficult these things can be at times, particularly at the beginning. It's been said the first steps are always the hardest ones to take. But as I'm oft to remind my patients, without them, of course, why we wouldn't even be walking! So allow me first to commend you both... for taking those steps today.
Thank you, doctor.
Before we sit down, are there any questions I can answer? Cathy looks to Frank who vaguely gestures ‘no.’
No? Alright. (to Frank) I suppose we may as well get started. Dr. Bowman gestures to the door and Cathy starts in first
Actually, Mrs. Whitaker, I think it might be best if your husband and I conversed - in private.
Oh. In private. Of course.
I think it's best.
Certainly. Then I'll - see you later, dear.
See you later. And they close the door behind them.
Cathy is motionless for a moment before turning back into waiting room and sitting down. She smiles at the receptio who vaguely smiles back. She looks back at the door.

Today, the general attitude regarding this sort, of behavior is, naturally, more modern, more scientific than it's ever been before. After all, we're not living in the dark ages. But for those who do seek treatment, who possess the will and desire to lead normal lives, there still remains only a scant, 5-to-30 percent rate of success. For complete heterosexual conversion. Interestingly, for many, it's the treatment itself that often changes the patient's mind. One thing is certain. A successful outcome is only ever achieved when it's what the patient himself desires more than anything else in the world.
What does it - comprise of? The treatment.
Treatment is usually comprised of psychiatric sessions, twice a week sometimes more.
Just - talking?
Yes. Though some patients have explored additional, more behavioral methods.
Behavioral?  45.
Electro-shock aversion therapy, for instance, or hormonal re-balancing procedures. But neither of these would be part of any standardized treatment. Silence. Frank looks down in thought.
I know it can all seem rather daunting at first. (leaning back in his chair) I suggest you take some time, think over the various options we discussed, discuss it with your wife -
No, I - I already know - I want to go ahead. Begin treatment. Frank tries to gather his thoughts.

I can't - let this thing destroy my life - my family's life! I know it's a sickness because it makes me feel - despicable, dirty. I promise you Dr. Bowman, I'm gonna beat this thing. I'm gonna break it. So help me God. The doctor is listening.
The door swings open and Cathy turns to see Frank and Dr. Bowman step into the waiting room.
So why don't you go ahead and confirm the times we discussed with Rosalyn. And I'll see you here same time next Tuesday. (they shake)
Thank you, doctor.  46. Cathy listens on, beaming with pleasure.
Mr. Whitaker. (leaning out toward Cathy) Mrs. Whitaker!
Thank you, doctor! Frank walks right past her. Cathy turns to catch up with
Cathy joins Frank in the paneled elevator. The door close a soft stir of music begins. Cathy looks over at Frank wh stares ahead, blankly.
Frank.
What?
I'm just proud of you, that's all.
Don't say that.
Well I am. And he seems like a very decent man, Dr. Bowman. Don't you think? He doesn't answer.
Frank?
I don't know, Cathleen. I suppose he's decent. The elevator doors open and Frank stalks through the lobb and out the door, music thickening. Cathy follows.  47.
Frank and Cathy walk out of the building into a strong wi Behind them an obscure, REAR-PROJECTED Hartford feels a million miles away.
But Frank, you must have liked him enough to want to see him again.
Who else am I going see?
Well - I'm sure there are numerous doctors - in Hartford or in Springfield - if you don't - if you aren't certain about - He stops sharply and turns to her.
Look! I just want to get the whole fucking thing over with! Can you understand that?! Cathy stares at him in shock and fear.
(eyes filling) Frank! Please don't - Frank takes her hand. Suddenly his eyes fill as well.
I'm sorry. I'm sorry. He embraces her.
Cathy, I'm so sorry. The music opens up.

We pull out from a large, framed version of the Mr.& Mrs. Magnavox ad, to a view of the whole bustling floor  48. The elevator doors open and we follow Frank as he walks d the central aisle toward his office. He nods to the regular cycle of greetings ('Good morning, Whitaker... Morning, sir'). He approaches Kitty's desk.
Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.
(a bit faintly) Kitty.
I hope you have a pleasant day, sir.
(glancing back vaguely) Thank you. He continues on to his office. There, he discovers Marlene standing at her desk holding broken desk lamp.
Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.
Marlene.
I found this in the cupboard, sir.
What's that?
Your desk lamp. Sir. The one that was missing. Frank lingers a moment, absently.
Ah.
Should I have it repaired, sir?  49.
Yes. Yes - (continuing into his office) Thank you, Marlene.
Uh - Mr. Whitaker, Mr. Fine's been - The door closes behind him.
Frank stands a moment facing the door in silence.
(off) Frank? Frank turns around to see Stan seated on a leather couch the window.
Didn't see you there!
(slight beat) Everything alright?
with me? (brushing it off) Oh... Frank sits down at his desk as Stan gets up, holding a la flat folder.
What's up.
Just picked up the galleys from the printer.
How do they look?
Great. Just great.  50.
Fine. Fine. (flipping through his appointment book) Why'n't you leave ‘em here and I'll - have a look the first chance I get.
(slightly perplexed) Sure. Stan walks over to the desk and sets down the folder.
You'll... let me know what you think?
Course I will. You're first on my list.
(before leaving) So what's it gonna take to get you back on that course, anyway? We haven't seen you for weeks!
I know it. I've just been...
Sunday. No excuses.
Alright.

I'm holding you to it! Stan leaves Frank alone at his desk. Staring straight ahe he reaches down to the bottom drawer and pulls out the bo of Scotch. He unscrews the top, closes his eyes and takes long, dark swig, music rising.

It's a cold, overcast day in the quiet, tree-lined neighborhood of the Blue Hills district, as Cathy and Ele emerge from the house carrying serving trays. Cathy's car parked in the driveway of Eleanor's modern Ranch-style ho
Thanks again, El.
You sure that's all I can give you?
Oh, yes. The caterers should have everything. I just thought a few extras would be nice. They approach Cathy's car.
Oh - And don't forget! The art show's Saturday so start working on Frank tonight. Cathy opens the car door and starts putting the trays ins
I swear he's the kind of man you have to pin messages to!

Though I'm sorry to say Mona Lauder will be attending. Turns out her uncle's in town, some hot-shot art- dealer from New York. I think I met him at one of Mona's soiree's. A bit flowery for my tastes.
How do you mean?
Oh, you know. A touch light on his feet?
You mean...  52.
Yes, darling. One of those. of course I could be mistaken. Just an impression I got.
You don't care for them particularly?
Well, no, not particularly. Not that I actually know any. Call me old-fashioned, I just like all the men I'm around to be all men. Say! Why the third degree?
It's not the third degree, I just - (climbing into her car) I'm interested, that's all. In your views. Eleanor doesn't look convinced.
I read an article recently. Ina magazine. (she closes the car door) - What?
Nothing! I'm just delighted to see you taking interest in yet another civic cause! I can see it now: "Cathleen Whitaker and her kindness to Homosexuals'!
Oh - that word. Cathy begins pulling out.
See you Sunday. And bring Frank!
I’ll try. Eleanor waves and starts back into the house as Cathy dri off.

Afternoon shadows stretch across the Whitaker’s block as Cathy turns the corner. She pulls into the driveway just Frank is getting out of his car and David, dressed in his baseball uniform, and Janice, in ballet clothes, come run to greet him.
Father’s home! Father’s home!
Well look who’s here. The little ballerina herself.
Hi-ya, pop!
(to David) Whaduya say, kiddo? Cathy steps out of her car just as Sybil appears to meet
What a lovely surprise, having you home at a decent hour. Thank you Sybil.
Marlene had me set for another dinner meeting but I just said to reschedule.
Oh, Frank. I’m so pleased you did. They embrace and Frank kisses her as the whole family fol Sybil into the house.
The Whitaker family are in the midst of a spirited dinner though it's clear all the enthusiasm in the room has begu drain Frank of his.
Then Billy Hutchison stole a pass at the ten yard line, pop. Ran it all the way for a touch down. You shoulda seen it!  54.
Father, wanna see my routine for the ballet recital?
I was talking to pop!
Children. Give your father a moment to eat his dinner. (to Frank) Another lambchop, dear?
I'm fine.
You sure? I have plenty in the oven.
I'm fine. Thank you. Small silence.
We're playing Lincoln on Saturday, pop. If you're not working.
Oh heavens, that reminds me! Darling, this Saturday is that reception I told you about, for the modern art show Eleanor's group was sponsoring. You remember?
Oh God.
I know how you hate these things but I simply have to go and Eleanor pleaded with me to ask you.
What about me! No one cares one bit what I'm doing Saturday! Like playing one of the toughest teams in the whole entire league!  55.
David I'm sorry but this one Saturday your mother has an engagement that simply can't be changed -
Pop could come. Cathy looks at Frank who is looking down.
Couldn't you, pop?
We'll see, David. No one talks for several seconds.
Janice, would you please pass the butter? Janice passes the butter to her mother.
Frank watches TV from bed. Cathy sits at her vanity doing hundred strokes, looking over at him while brushing.
Frank?
Hmm.
(brief silence) Did you see him?
Yea.
When?
Yesterday.  56.
You didn't say a word. He continues staring at the TV.
So how was it? With Bowman? Did you feel -
It's fine.
(putting down the brush coaxing) And there's nothing more you care to share with your very own adoring wife?
Cathleen, what I discuss with this doctor. It's private. That's - part of it. Alright? I'm sorry.
I understand, dear. I do. Cathy looks at him a moment before lifting up the brush a turning back to the mirror.
Oh and Frank, wait'll you see the hors d'oeuvres! The caterers are doing such a marvelous job. I think you're going to be very pleased this year, darling. I really do.

A frolic of music rises as we survey a busy corner within Hartford cultural district A small bustle of ladies and their husbands are milling around the entrance to a spacious, private gallery. The easled sign in the front window reads:

head_text.subj: PRINTS BY THE MASTERS OF MODERN ART

text: Finally, Cathy comes running up to the door of the galler

Cathy squeezes past clusters of visitors holding glasses wine when she spots Eleanor standing in front of a large Christmas tree. Eleanor is chatting with MONA LAUDER, an imposing, chinless brunette (fortyish), and MR. FARNSWORT Mona’s uncle, a rotund middle-aged man with died ginger h and a waxed mustache.
Eleanor - darling! I’m so sorry I’m late.
Cathleen!
Hello Mona.

Darling, I want to introduce you to my uncle, Morris Farnsworth, a wickedly successful Gotham art dealer who was kind enough to attend our provincial little gathering. Morris darling, allow me to introduce my dear little friend Cathleen Whitaker - whose face and civic fancies are hardly strangers to the society pages of Hartford!
Oh Mona, really. You must ignore her, Mr. Farnsworth. Mr. Farnsworth extends his hand.
(rather affected) Charmed.
I hope you enjoy your stay.
Morris was just telling us the most delightful tale. All about a forged Rembrandt!  58.

Well there's really not much more to it than that. You can only imagine my utter disdain in discovering the gifts of so masterful an impersonator in as base and uncivilized a character as the man ultimately convicted of the crime.
It's fascinating, isn't it?
Cathy, darling, don't let us keep you. I know you want to see the show.
I am dying to see it.
Oh yes. It's simply charming. Eleanor you should be so proud.
Why thank you, Mona.
Lovely meeting you, Mr. Farnsworth.
Likewise, my dear. Cathy throws Eleanor a little smile as she starts off int the gallery.
Cathy stands in front of a beautiful Picasso ‘crying woma Suddenly - FLASH! - Cathy turns to see Mrs. Leacock standing beside her photographer.
Pardon me, dear, but it was too lovely to resist: Wife of Hartford Executive Communing With Picasso!
Mrs. Leacock. Lovely to see you again.  59.
And how is that charming husband of yours?

He's very well, thank you - Cathy stops suddenly, spotting someone across the room. Raymond is standing with his daughter SARAH (age 11), lea over her and discussing one of the pictures on the wall. surprisingly, they're the only black faces in the room.)
Mrs. Leacock, would you excuse me a moment?
Certainly, dear. Cathy smiles and starts over to Raymond and his little gi as Mrs. Leacock and the photographer observe. Raymond looks up and sees Cathy approaching. He smiles an stands.
Mrs. Whitaker! Hello!
Raymond. What a tremendous surprise - finding you here. Is this your daughter?
Yep. This is Sarah. Sarah, this is Mrs. Whitaker. Mrs. Whitaker owns one of the gardens I look after
Hello, Sarah.
Hello.

(spotting something out front) Say, Sarah, isn't that Hutch and his little brother I see, playing out front?  60. Raymond directs Sarah's attention to the front of the gal where Billy Hutchison. (HUTCH, age 11) and two other whit boys can be seen through the glass, playing with paper airplanes.
You remember them, don't you, baby? Sarah shakes her head, sullenly.
Sure you do. The day we went to Mrs. Hutchison's house.
(softly) Oh, yea.

What do you say about going out and seeing if they'd like to play for a little while? How does that sound? Sarah looks at her father. It's clear it's the very last thing she wants to do, but is too shy to say anything in front of Cathy.
Aww, there's nothing to be afraid of.
(softly) I know...
It's only polite to say hello to people you've met in the past. Ah, go on, give it a try. For daddy. Sarah looks down, turns slowly and starts reluctantly tow the front of the gallery.
Attagirl!
Oh Raymond, she’s lovely.
Thank you.  61.
And how wonderful of you to expose her - to art and culture this way.
Well, my mother, she was always trying to expose my brothers and I to the finer things, and we fought her every step of the way. I guess I’m sort of making up for bad behavior.
But how on earth did you hear about this show?
Well I do read the papers.
Well of course you do. I just meant - it was such a coincidence.
I know. I was just teasing you.
(slightly lower voice) Because you know I’m not prejudiced. Raymond smiles at her.
(quite serious) My husband and I have always believed in equal right for the Negro, and support the NACP.
Well I’m glad to hear that.
I just - I wanted you to know.
Well thank you.
Not at all.  62. As they start into the final room of the gallery we see S through the window outside, watching as the boys try unsuccessfully to launch their paper airplane.
Close on Hutch's paper airplane as his friend, Tommy, giv it a throw.
Go! The plane nosedives and Hutch goes to get it.
Straighter, Tommy! You gotta throw it straighter. And hard! One, two, three - GO! Tommy throws it hard but it sputters down once again. Sarah giggles to herself.
It's too heavy! The boys stop and turn.
What?
On the end. Your airplane!
Who asked you?! C’mon, Bobby. Hutch motions to the others and the boys start back into gallery.
Hutch and his brother return to their parents as Sarah watches from outside, alone.
Cathy and Raymond are looking at a Miro.  63.
So what is your opinion on modern art?
It's hard to put into words really. I just know what I care for and what I" don't. Like this - I'm not sure how you pronounce it - Mirra?
Miro.
Miro. I don't know why but I just adore it. The feeling it gives. I know that sounds terribly vague.
No. It actually confirms something I've always wondered about modern art, abstract art.
What is that?

That perhaps it's just picking up where religious art left off. You know. Trying to somehow show you divinity, put it up there on the wall. The modern artist just pares it down to the most basic elements of shape and color. But when you look at that Miro, you feel it just the same.

Why that's lovely, Raymond. We hear the brief shriek of a woman's laugh. Cathy turns Mona Lauder, Mr. Farnsworth and two other women, one stif her giggles, snickering amongst themselves over Cathy and Eleanor, who is standing listening to an ELDERLY WOMAN, a notices the commotion.
To tell you the truth, I was rather shocked by the prices. (MORE)
ELDERLY WOMAN(cont 'd) But then I've always preferred the work of the masters... Rembrandt, Michelangelo - Eleanor spots Cathy saying goodbye to Raymond and startin off down the hall.
I'm terribly sorry - Would you excuse me a moment?
Certainly. Eleanor starts after Cathy.
Cathleen!
El, honey. It all looks just marvelous - Eleanor whisks Cathy to the side.
Cathy, who on earth was that man? You have the whole place ina clamor!
Oh for heavens sake, why? Because of that ridiculous story?
(squinting off at Raymond) Who is he? Raymond is now introducing Sarah to a smiling, middle-age woman in a hat.
His name's Raymond Deagan. He's Otis Deagan's son.
Your gardener?
Yes. He passed away very recently and Raymond's taken over his business.  65.
Well you certainly seem on familiar terms with the man.
Oh what does that mean? Familiar terms? He happens to have some very enlightening views on Miro. (glancing at her watch) Oh, jeepers, would you look at the time! El, I have to fly.
They start walking toward the door.
I'm having the carpets cleaned for tomorrow.
What time are the caterers showing?
They said four.
I'll come early too. For moral support!
You're a doll. Cathy waves bye and dashes out of the gallery.

Music accompanies a slow and stately ascent upon the Whit house, trimmed with cars and bursting from inside with th exuberance of the annual company party. We can even hear distant clamor of merriment and laughter churning from within.

The house, impeccably decorated, is swarming with people evening dress, drinking, smoking, chatting, laughing. An overstuffed Christmas tree glistens in the corner as an endless parade of hors d'oeuvres are passed solemnly by t all-black, formally uniformed, serving staff.  66. Cathy shimmers in a gown of sapphire blue, standing surrounded at one end of the room, while Frank stands wit drink in hand, surrounded at the other. We see various faces from the Magnavox office, including Marlene. Cathy is listening to a middle-aged Elderly Woma

Not to say that I'm against integration mind you. I do believe it's the Christian thing to. But I still say what happened in Little Rock could just as easily have happened here in Hartford. A stout, red-faced man answers.
Nonsense!
And why is that?

Well for one thing, there's no Governor Faubus in Connecticut. But the main reason - They're no Negroes! (laughs) Two of the serving staff close enough to have heard his remark continue serving. DICK DAWSON, a tall, strapping man in his mid-30's, is leaning on a chair beside Cathy.
No, but I do hear there are some rather dangerous pro-integration types. Right here in Hartford!
Dangerous?
Oh yes. Some very attractive ones in fact. Noted, I'm told, for their kindness to Negroes!
(slapping his arm) Oh Dick, stop! Where on earth did you hear about that?  67.
Shirley read it to me.
I should have known.
What's all this?

Absolutely nothing! Here, let me freshen those. Cathy takes Dick and the red-faced man's glasses and star off toward the bar. Frank is at the couch with Stan Fine, Doreen and her husband RON. As Cathy passes, Stan calls o to her.
By golly there she is now! Prettiest gal in the room!
Oh, Stan! Liquor does bring out the Texan in you. I just hope Eleanor isn't listening.
(putting an arm around her) So what if she is! I still say Frank's the luckiest guy in town.
Here, here! Frank is hunched over listening, noticeably intoxicated.
(thinking he's being witty) Smoke and mirrors, fellas! That's all it is. You should see her without her face on! Frank laughs at his own joke and a few join in awkwardly.
Erank!  68.
No, he's absolutely right. We ladies are never really what we appear. And every girl has her secrets!
I'll say.
(thrusting his glass at her) Well how ‘bout this girl going and getting her husband another drink? How ‘bout that?
(still smiling) You don't think you might have - already had enough, darling?
No, I don't think I've already had -

(interrupting, raising her glass) Well I'd just like to take a moment to raise a glass to our marvelous host and hostess and another glorious Annual Party at the Whitaker's! To Frank and Cathy, truly Mr. and Mrs. Magnavox! Everyone around them raises their glasses ‘To Frank and Cathy’ and toasts. Cathy and Frank smile and nod at their guests, but the strain is evident
Thank you... Now who can I freshen up? Ron?
I'm fine.
Me.
I think you're fresh enough. Cathy starts off toward the bar. Sybil is crossing with a tray.
Wonderful party, Cathleen.
Thank you.
Here, Mrs. Whitaker those.
Thank you, Sybil. let me take Eleanor approaches Cathy as she finishes giving Sybil the empty glasses.
Cathy?
Hi. Eleanor pulls her aside, by a window. him so
Honey? Is everything alright?
What do you mean?
Frank. I've never seen soused.
Oh, no. He's just been hard lately. He's been tremendous strain.
You sure that's all?
Oh, yes.
You'd tell me if there more?
Of course I would. - working so under such was anything  70. Eleanor puts a hand on Cathy's back as they start back in the party.
By the way, kid. I think we just threw ourselves one class-A swanky function.
It did turn nicely, didn't it. A WOMAN calls out to Cathy.
Cathleen, darling. You've simply outdone yourself - once again!
Cathy stands at the door waving goodbye to the last guest (probably Eleanor & Stan)

Thanks for everything! I'll call you tomorrow! Goodnight! Cathy closes the door and steps into the half-darkened ho still strewn with party debris. She takes a deep breath o relief, and notices Eleanor's serving-ware by the bar.
Oh, shoot - I forgot to give Eleanor her servers. Frank sits in an armchair, rouged in shadow. Cathy walks toward the stairs and stops, looking at him.
Frank? He doesn't respond, and she continues on toward the stair

You never let me stay over

Oh, it is them, it is! Oh thank you, mother! Thank you, father! Take your pick, darling. It's your choice.
This mean you're paying?
Well Rio, I know, is a bit extravagant, but the rest are really all quite affordable. As far as warm weather goes. This time of year.
I don't know. Stan's always raving about Miami.
Oh, Frank I think Miami would be a dream! El says it's just darling. Everything's pink.
Oh yea? (tiny pause) Then maybe we oughta consider Bermuda. Cathy looks at him. Frank cracks a little smile. Music sweeps up as Cathy embraces him.
Oh, Frank! I do love you, darling. I do. 108.
Music can be heard spilling out from the glittering suppe club, jutting off the side of the modern, palm-lined reso  109.

Cathy and Frank dance together on the terrace of the sparkling venue, all decked out for New Year's, under the stars. A small band is playing and several other couples dancing. And though it's not without tension it's clear t are each trying to make the vacation as pleasant as can b
I must say you look extremely fetching all gussied up in your white tux and tie.

Yes. Very much. Didn't I say?
You did not.

That's more like it. The song ends and everyone claps for the band. Frank kiss Cathy tenderly on the lips, under the stars, and she smil into his eyes. The handsome middle-aged parents sit down first, followed by five blond, handsome children ranging from late teens to late 20's in age. The BLOND FA addresses Frank and Cathy:
Excuse us.

You have a lovely family.

Happy New Year to you. Frank nods to the table, catching another glimpse of the pretty blond boy's stare. And he and Cathy take their sea
Frank, do you remember that summer? At your uncle's in Vermont? Janice wasn't even born yet. When David broke his finger on the water pump?

Think Margaret eventually put it on the market.
That was a wonderful old place. All those wonderful barbeques.
It was a good summer - (distracted by the noise)

It must be almost time. Cathy lifts her glass and Frank refills it, then refills own. He glances over toward the ruckus from other tables. ... Five - four - three - two - one
Cathy and Frank toast their champagne and kiss through th rain of pale blue confetti and all the shimmering cheer surrounding them.
Happy New Year, darling!
Happy New Year, dear Music swirls.

We are surveying a pleasing aqua-blue scene of pleasure-g by the pool. Frank is just finishing some laps and stops at the shallo end to catch his breath. He sits down on a step, still ha submerged, and smiles at the mothers of the splashing toddlers. He notices something at the other end of the po A few members of the blond family are just coming out dressed in swimwear and robes. They grab a few lounges an chairs and start to settle. The pretty son doesn't seem t among them. Frank stands, stretches. His father, a HOTEL WAITER, is running over from the hut- style snack-bar.

(calling out) Martin! Martin, get outa there! You know you're not allowed in there! Cathy, who sits among a row of lounges under an umbrella, looks up from her magazine. (forcefully) Now what did I tell you about going in that pool?! You know you're not allowed in there! He carries his crying boy off. Frank turns toward Cathy and shrugs. He starts back, dryi himself off on the way.
Hello, there.
Well hello. Frank plops himself down on the lounge, flat on his back, exhales.
Mmmm. Good swim, darling?
(eyes closed, nodding) Mmm.
Feel good?
Mmm.

Isn't the sun just marvelous? But her expression changes when she glances back toward t pool. Kids who were playing now stare across the pool to the shallow end blankly. The last few bathers near the steps just stepping out of the water, leaving the entire area cleared. A MOTHER in an unbecoming swimsuit calls out to her DAUGH
Donna?  113.
What?
Time to get out.
But why?

(sharply) Because I said so. The daughter starts swimming reluctantly to the edge, jus the man doing laps makes his final pass. Before turning back, Frank takes a final glance at the bl family gathering. The pretty son has just arrived, wearing a white terry-cl robe and a beach bag over his shoulder. He doesn't notice Frank. Well that does it. Frank turns.
I think I've heard quite enough about fashion and advice for one afternoon! I do believe it's time for my Miss Mitchell. Cathy opens up her canvas bag but doesn't see her book.
Oh, heavens.
What?
I must have left it in the room. So silly.  114.
You want me to go?
No, darling. You just sat down.
I don't mind. (he sits up)
What? No, Frank. I’ll go. Frank stands up and flexes.
It’s fine. I want to get a paper anyway.
You sure?
Yea. He grabs his shirt and room-key and starts off toward the room - in the opposite direction of the blond boy by the pool.

Thank you, darling. I’m sure it’s just there on the night-stand. INT. FRANK’S ROOM - DAY Frank has left the door ajar as he gathers his wallet and Cathy’s book. He stops for a second in front of the mirro and regards himself in his wear. Not bad, for a man his a Then suddenly he senses something. Slowly, like a sleepwalker, Frank begins to approach, mus deepening. FADE TO BLACK.
They're here! I see their car! They're here!
Music lightens as David, Janice and Sybil all hurry to th door which flies open on Cathy and Frank, armored with gi and luggage.
Mother! Father!
Hi-ya pop! Hey mother!
Welcome home, Mr. And Mrs. Whitaker.
Well look at you all! what a lovely greeting!
So mother was it dreamy?
Listen to you! Dreamy!
(taking Mr. Whitaker's suitcase) Did you have a nice time Mr. Whitaker?
Yes, Sybil. It was very relaxing.
Say, pop!  116.
David, help Sybil with the luggage. Frank sits down on the living room sofa as Sybil starts u the stairs with a suitcase.
Pop, you'll never guess what happened at school this week? Try and guess!
I give up.
David!
(lugging a suitcase up the stairs) I'm helping, mother!
Billy Hutchison and these two other boys all got expelled from school!
You mean suspended. Sybil is starting back down the stairs.
No! Expelled! I swear! For throwing a rock at a girl's head.
That's terrible. A little girl from school?
No. She was a Negro.
What? Who told you such a thing?
Tommy Hawkings. He saw. So he had to tell the principal. Cathy glances up at Sybil who continues slowly down the stairs.  117.
Sybil? Is this true? Sybil glances over to Frank and back to Cathy.
Yes, ma'am. I'm afraid it is. Cathy looks over at Frank incredulously.
What in heaven's name has gotten into this town?
It's just a couple of foolish kids.
Hutch said they were just trying to teach her a lesson. Sybil continues on into the kitchen.
Well I think it's dreadful. And you're certainly not to see that Hutch boy again. You understand me?
Yes, ma’am.
While you're there David, how about flipping on the set for your old man.
Sure, pop. Cathy sighs, picking up the mail from the hall table, and starts upstairs.

Cathy enters the dark room, flips on the light and puts d her things. She walks over to the small desk by the windo and puts down the mail. There, among the bills, she notices the NAACP brochure. S picks it up.  118. Close on brochure, music taking.

Cathy’s finger is scanning the telephone book for a listi and comes to rest on a number for the NAACP Information L Then she lifts the receiver off the phone and starts dial She is sitting at the dining room table, half-toned by a of wintery light, while Janice sits at the coffee table d her homework.

Father’s home!

You didn’t say anything. He starts taking off his coat and mittens by the coat-rac

Yes, mother.

Did I tell you the pediatrician thinks Janice is going to need braces?
Father, do I have to!
Apparently our little girl has an over -bite. David rushes in from the backyard carrying a bucket and r

In the garage.

Yes ma’am.

Frank! Janice and David are stunned, staring at their father
Frank! What's the matter - ! She gets up from her chair and starts over to him, a dark mist of music forming.
Oh - God! Janice begins to cry.  121.
(urgently) Janice. David. Go upstairs to your rooms. Janice stands, sobbing. David remains, transfixed.
Now! Janice runs up the stairs and David follows in a trance. Cathy stands frozen near the foot of the stairs.
(crying) Oh - Cathy... She approaches him but slowly, with a strange foreboding.
What, Frank. What is it?
Something happened...
What? (nothing) What.
Frank cries almost like a baby.
I’ve fallen in love with someone. Cathy stares.
Who wants to be with me. For a moment, just having said it sobers him some, and he looks back at her. Then he crumbles again.

(lifeless) I assume then... you'll be wanting a divorce? Frank looks up at her, puffy-eyed. But suddenly the tears seem to have stopped. Cathy looks back at him like a stone.
(softly) Cathy I’m so sorry. But all at once she turns, and picking up a glass from th table walks straight-headed up the stairs.
Cathy enters, closes the door and stands frozen, in the d for several seconds.

Eleanor reaches for Cathy's hands, music settling.
Oh, Cathy.
So you see, El. You see why I couldn't tell you anything. Anything at all.
Oh you dear, sweet kid. Ina million years I couldn't have imagined. Not Frank! I suppose divorce really is the only option - if only to keep it as far from the children as possible.
I think that's what's been the hardest of all. The endless secrecy. Our entire lives just - shut in the dark.
Are there savings?  124.
Nothing much to speak of. And certainly not with Frank's job on the line.
Well honey, you know, if there's anything you need, anything at all -
Oh, El...
I mean it. We're here. Alright?
Thank you, El. For always having been. Cathy reflects a moment and stands, walking toward the window.
You know it's funny.
What's that.
This whole time, the only person I've been able to talk to. About any of this. (turning back to her) Was Raymond Deagan. Eleanor looks at Cathy in disbelief.
What?
It’s true. Well, not in the way Mona intended - Nothing like that! We would just talk! But... Somehow it made me feel - oh, I don’t know. Alive somewhere.
She glances out the window at the rain-dampened snow.
Oh Eleanor, I know it sounds ridiculous and mad... (MORE)
CATHY(cont 'd) But I do, I think of him. What he’s doing, what he’s thinking. I do - Cathy turns back to her friend with the wistful smile of girl. Eleanor glances off.
El? Eleanor gets up and starts tending to the tray of empty c
What can I say? You’re so full of surprises. I’m speechless. Cathy looks at her.
What do you mean?
(little laugh) Though I'm sure I must have looked entirely the fool, crusading away against Mona Lauder and all her so- called inventions-!
Eleanor! - How can you say such a thing?
I didn't say a word! who am I to tell anyone how to lead their lives?
But El! Nothing happened between us! I told you that!
Cathy it's none of my business. But you certainly make it sound as if something had. A soft bed of music rises as Cathy looks back at her disarmed.

Music continues as Cathy returns home, hanging up her coa and stepping into the dark, silent house. She walks toward the french doors, etched in silver, and stops. There, filtering moonlight through its gilded maze, the branch of Silver-tip spruce still sits in a vase by the window.
(off) Mrs. Whitaker? Cathy turns toward the kitchen. Sybil stands in the shadows near the kitchen door.
Sybil.
I'm sorry to disturb you ma'am, I just...
Yes, Sybil?
It's something I've been wanting to tell you, ma'am, for some time - Something I believe you'd surely want to know - even if it isn't... exactly my place...
Sybil, what is it?
It's about the little colored girl, ma'am. The one that got hit?
Yes. What about her?
I'm sorry, ma'am, but it was Mr Deagan's little girl, Sarah -  127.
What! Oh God, Sybil, it wasn't!
The neighbors tell me she's doing just fine -
Oh that dear, sweet little girl. (to Sybil, suddenly incensed) How in God's name, Sybil, could you not have told me this? That was weeks ago - !
She turns and marches to the entry hall, Sybil following.
Oh, Mrs. Whitaker, please don't be cross with me! I didn't want to - makes things any worse!
(throwing on her coat) Sybil, Sybil do you have any idea where Mr. Deagan lives?
I believe he's been at his father's old place on 12th and Governor.
12th and Governor. Thank you Sybil. Cathy grabs her purse and opens the door, rain falling.
You’re going there now?
Please just keep an eye on the children for me. I won’t be long. (she starts out)
Mrs. Whitaker!
(turns back, hurriedly) What?  128.
Would you like me to go with you ma’ am?
No, Sybil. No. I’ll be fine. Thank you. Music billows as Sybil watches her go.

Rain falls upon the inky, lamp-lit night as we loom down slowly upon a small, wood bungalow, the front windows of which appear to have been boarded up. Through the window downstairs we can just glimpse Raymond walking past.
Raymond is bringing a freshly made cup of hot chocolate i the living room, stirring as he goes.

And here we have it! Your daddy's super-duper world-renowned hot cocoa specially prepared for his super-duper number one girl! He hands the cup to Sarah who is stretched out on the cou with pillow and blanket watching TV. A small, square band on her forehead still marks her injury.
Thank you, daddy.
How you feeling, baby?
Fine, daddy.
What's that you're watching, anyway? There's a knock at the door. Raymond stops.  129.
Who on earth...? He walks to the front.
Yes? The door opens on Cathy, turning suddenly to face him.
Raymond! Oh Raymond I just heard. Just this instant. I heard and I got in my car. (she stops) How are you? How's Sarah?
We're fine. Thank you. A car passes and Raymond looks out nervously.
(semi-whisper, gesturing) Meet me around the side. Cathy nods and starts back down the steps as Raymond step back inside the house.
(grabbing his coat) Sarah, everything's alright, honey. I'll just be outside for a minute.
Okay daddy.
Cathy stands facing away, softly illuminated by an outdoo lamp, along the side of Raymond's bungalow. She hears footsteps and turns. Raymond stands near the corner of the house, looking at h
Oh Raymond. (taking a few steps closer) What you must have been through. Raymond looks down and shuffles forward some as well.  130.
What's being done, to the boys who-?
Nothing. I won't make her go through it again. Not now. Not with rocks coming through the window every night.
Raymond, that's hateful.
It's not white's throwing them - it's coloreds.
No.
Oh, yea - Seems to be the one place where whites and coloreds are in full harmony. Anyway, we'll be out of here soon enough, once and for all.
You're moving?
Yea.
Where to?
I have a... (emptying some flooded trash-lids) brother in Baltimore. Says he can find me work out there. So we're packing up the house. Two weeks Friday we'll be on the 4:30 train, heading South.
But what about your business, your shop?
The business is through. No one's gonna hire me. (MORE)
RAYMOND( cont'd) So I'm selling the shop to a cousin of mine. No... (he looks off) It's pretty well finished for me here. (a thought stops him) I've never lived anywhere but Hartford.

(all vulnerability) Perhaps... sometime in the future... after you're settled - I could... perhaps come for a visit See Baltimore? You see I... Well it looks as if I'm to be single again. Raymond looks at her. It makes him sad. He smiles softly. Silence.
Oh, Mrs. Whitaker.
(softly) Please call me Cathy.
(softly) Cathy.
No one would know us there.
I'm just not sure... it would be such a wise idea. After... well, everything that’s - Cathy looks at him, feeling the first chill of an impendi loss.

All that matters now - what’s got to matter most - is what’s right for Sarah. I’ve learned my lesson about mixing with other worlds. And I’ve seen the sparks fly... (tenderly) All kinds. Cathy turns away, hiding sudden tears.  132. Raymond puts a hand on her shoulder, which she covers wit hers.
Have a proud life. A splendid life. Will you do that? She closes her eyes. He kisses her fingertips.

Goodbye Cathy. His fingers slip from hers. She stands a moment, the black, liquid sky continuing its downpour, then starts walking, hurriedly, to her car. She doesn’t look back. Raymond watches gravely, then turns and starts slowly bac inside. To which a rising music as bottomless as the sea suddenly answers, spilling over and engulfing what follows.

The curtains are drawn and Cathy lays across the shadowy surface of her bed, sobbing. Everything she's kept inside seems to spill from her now, as we move in gently through aquanautic shadows. Music fades, leaving us alone with her sounds - when the phone starts ringing. Cathy stops, listening. Then sits u bed and looks over at it, wiping her eyes. Then she slips the edge of the bed and walks over to the writing table t answer it. Outside, the rain appears to have stopped.
Hello?
(through receiver) Cathy? Did I wake you?
Frank?  133.
Frank sits on the phone against blue floss hotel wallpape his face in shadow.
I’m sorry to call this late. I hope I didn’t...
No. I was awake.
(through receiver) I didn’t want to - upset the children.
No. Of course.
(through receiver) How are they, by the way?
Fine. Just fine. They still ask when you'll be coming home.

I know. I know. I guess that's - partly why I was calling... Frank sits hunched-over a little table in the dark. Behin him, spread out in bed with newspapers and a half-eaten b of chocolates, the pretty blond boy watches a large Tv.
I, uh - I got a call from Dick yesterday. Said everything was... set, papers drawn up.
Cathy just listens. Expressionless.  134.

(through receiver) He wanted to know... how Thursday was for you. Three o'clock sometime. I told him I thought you might have carpool Thursdays but I wasn't absolutely certain. So I said I would check.
(distantly) You never could remember my carpool days. And they've always been the same, Wednesdays and Fridays, as long as I can remember.
(through receiver) Wednesdays and Fridays. Of course. Same old absent-minded -
What time... did you say on Thursday?
(through receiver) What?
The appointment? What time?
(through receiver) Oh - Three. Three o'clock.
(brief silence) Alright.
(through receiver) Okay. Well... Great. That was it really. I know it's late.
It is.
(through receiver) So I guess I'll see you on - Thursday, then.  135.
See you Thursday.
Goodbye, Cathy.

Outside, through the bedroom window, we can see the new gardener - an Asian man - watering the plants. We slowly inside to find Cathy sitting at her bedroom table finishi up the bills.

(writing) Sixty-seven dollars and thirty-two cents. (looking up a moment) Now what is today...? She glances over at her desk-calendar, turning the page t the proper day. It reads: SATURDAY, MARCH 1. No reason not to keep things up Mrs. Whitaker. No reason at all.
I know. Cathy stops in front of the mirror to fix her hair and pu her sunglasses.

Oh! Thank you, Sybil - (she starts checking her pockets) I don't know how in the world I'd ever manage - Here it is. She takes out the shopping list but finds something else the pocket. I shouldn't be long, Sybil.
(still bent over, polishing) Alright, Mrs. Whitaker.  137. Cathy turns, music rising, and starts out the door

Cathy drives up in front of the large green field, stuffe with boys in red, sauntering back to the bleachers. David amongst them, walking arm-in-arm with another boy, when h spots his mother’s car and waves.
